column1: Cardigan: Average of 12 years and two months[3]Pembroke: Average of 12 years and three months[4]Dog (domestic dog)
The Pembroke Welsh Corgi (/ˈkɔːrɡi/[5] or Corgi
column3: or occasionally the etymologically consistent Corgwn; /ˈkɔːrɡuːn/) is a small type of herding dog that originated in Wales. The name corgi is derived from the Welsh words cor and ci (which is mutated to gi)
column4: meaning "dwarf" and "dog"
column5: respectively.

column1: Two separate breeds are recognized: the Pembroke Welsh Corgi and the Cardigan Welsh Corgi. There are physical differences between the two different breeds. According to the breed standards
column3: both in weight and height. Their tails are of different shapes
column4: and docking was previously performed on corgis before the practice was largely banned.

column2: the Pembroke has been attributed to the influx of dogs alongside Flemish weavers from around the 10th century
column3: while the Cardigan is attributed to the dogs brought with Norse settlers
column4: in particular a common ancestor of the Swedish Vallhund.

column1: The Pembroke is the more popular of the two
column2: yet still appears on The Kennel Club's vulnerable dog breeds of the United Kingdom list.[6] The Pembroke Welsh Corgi gained in popularity because Elizabeth II had personally owned more than 30 Pembrokes or Corgi-Dachshund crosses
column3: known as dorgis.

column1: Pembrokeshire and Cardiganshire are adjoining historical agricultural counties in South West Wales.[7] Welsh Corgis were cattle herding dogs; the type of herding dog referred to as "heelers"
column2: meaning that they would nip at the heels of the larger animals to keep them on the move.[8] The combination of their low height off the ground and the innate agility of Welsh Corgis would allow them to avoid the hooves of cattle.[8] The term "Corgi" means either cur dog or dwarf dog (cor = dwarf
column3: gi = lenitive of ci
column4: dog) in the Welsh language
column5: which was not intended as an insult to the dog's size
column6: rather as a purely descriptive term.[7][9] Different tales have been told of the Corgi's origin: some believe that the two modern breeds evolved from shared ancestry
column7: [10] while others attribute the import of the Pembroke Welsh Corgi to Flemish weavers starting around the 10th century.[11] Further theories on the origin of the Pembroke variety suggest that they may have originated from central European herding breeds from the area around modern Germany. Depending on the time period when these dogs were imported to Wales
column8: they could have been either Deutsche Bracken or Dachshund.[9]

column1: The Cardigan Welsh Corgi has been attributed to the influences of Nordic settlers in the region.[12] Dogs of similar dimensions exist in modern Scandinavia
column3: [13] and it is claimed by some historians that these two breeds share a common ancestor.[14] In the late 19th century
column4: farmers began to switch from cattle to sheep but the corgi is not suited for working sheep. Similarities between the Welsh Corgis have been attributed to cross-breeding between the two
column5: or simply selected breeding from those who wished to have the Cardigan variety appear closer in nature to the Pembroke.[14]

column1: The first recorded date for Corgis appearing in the show ring in Wales is 1925. Captain J. P. Howell called together a meeting of breeders of both the Pembroke and the Cardigan varieties and formed the Welsh Corgi Club
column2: with an initial membership of 59 members. A general breed standard was drawn up
column3: and Corgis began to appear in conformation shows. Until this point
column4: neither breed had been specifically bred for looks. Members of this club were primarily interested in the Pembroke variety
column5: although the Cardigan variety also appeared. At that point the breeds were referred to as the Pembrokeshire and Cardiganshire varieties; the names were later shortened. There were a number of disputes between breeders of the two types in early shows
column6: as judges who were breeders of one type would often favour them.[15] The Welsh Corgi appeared at Crufts—a dog show held annually in the United Kingdom—for the first time in 1927.[16]

column1: The first Championship was awarded at a Cardiff show in 1928
column2: to a red and white Pembroke bitch named Shan Fach. The breeds continued to be judged together until 1934 when The Kennel Club recognized each breed separately. In that initial registration
column3: some 59 Cardigans and 240 Pembrokes were listed in the pedigree books. The decisions about the breed to which each dog belonged were sometimes left to the owners
column4: who were free to choose whichever they felt was the most appropriate.[15] The first dog to be named Best in Show at an open conformation show was Ch. Bowhit Pivot.[17]

column1: Cardigan Welsh Corgis continued to be rarer than Pembrokes
column2: with only 11 registrations made in 1940. Both breeds survived the Second World War
column3: although the Cardigans registered with the Kennel Club numbered only 61 by the end of the war.[15] Pembrokes became very popular during the post war years in the United Kingdom; in 1953 it was ranked as the fourth most popular breed by the Kennel Club
column4: behind the English Cocker Spaniel
column5: the German Shepherd and the Pekingese.[18] In 1955
column6: the reserve Best in Show at Crufts was the Pembroke Welsh Corgi Kaytop Maracas Mint.[19] The Corgi breeds declined in popularity: veterinary physician Brian Singleton suggested in The Times in 1963 that this was due to issues with their temperament.[20]

column1: The Cardigan Welsh Corgi was listed in the Kennel Club's first list of Vulnerable Native Breeds in 2006.[21] This list is for those breeds which register less than 300 dogs in any one year;[22] there had been 84 Cardigan Corgis registered in 2006. After an initial increase
column3: but then rose to the highest numbers since the list began in 2015
column4: with a total of 124 puppies registered.[21] In 2013
column5: the Pembroke Welsh Corgi was also added
column6: as there had been only 241 puppies registered that year. While the Kennel Club blamed this on the importation of foreign dog breeds
column7: [22] The Daily Telegraph blamed the decline on the ban on tail docking introduced six years before.[23] However
column8: 2015 saw an increase of 34% in the number of Pembroke registrations; the popularity of Corgis on Instagram was credited for the change. Pembrokes were removed from the Vulnerable Native Breeds list in 2016.[24][25]

column1: In 1933 the first Welsh Corgis were brought to the United States by American breeder Mrs. Lewis Roesler
column2: for her Merriedip Kennels in the Berkshire Hills of Massachusetts. She had previously been well known for breeding Old English Sheepdogs. Roesler purchased a Pembroke corgi
column3: Little Madam
column4: at London's Paddington Station for £12. Wanting a mate for the dog
column5: she visited several Corgi kennels and bought a dog called Captain William Lewis. The American Kennel Club (AKC) first registered Welsh Corgis in 1934
column7: and Little Madam was the first registered animal of the breed. The first litter was registered later that year
column8: by Mr. E.M. Tidd in Oakland
column10: from a bitch named Toots which he had purchased in Canada.[17]

column1: Tidd imported Ch. Bowhit Pivot for his breeding lines in 1935
column2: registering him with the AKC as Sierra Bowhit Pivot. In addition to his British titles
column3: he became the first Corgi to be awarded the Champion status in the US
column4: and the first such dog to be named Best of Group at a conformation show in the United States. The Pembroke Welsh Corgi club was formed in 1937
column5: [17] and the first show was held at Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge's Giralda Farms in New Jersey. Following the Second World War
column6: there were imports from the United Kingdom
column7: including Rozavel Uncle Sam which dominated the show circuit for Corgis. In 1949
column8: he became the first Pembroke winner of Best in Show at an open conformation show in the United States. By 1998
column9: the Pembroke Welsh Corgi had become the 37th most popular breed of dog in the US.[26]

column1: A pair of Cardigan Welsh Corgis were imported to the US in 1931
column2: but the first member of that breed to be registered with the AKC was Blodwen of Robinscroft in 1935. They have never had the draw in the US given to the Corgis of the Pembroke type. In 1997
column3: some 752 Cardigan Welsh Corgis were registered with the AKC
column4: compared to 8
column5: 281 of the Pembrokes.[26]

column1: A Cardigan Welsh Corgi (left) and a Pembroke Welsh Corgi (right)
There are two breeds of Welsh Corgis
column3: each named for the county in Wales where it originated. The dogs share several similar traits
column4: such as their coats
column5: which are water-resistant and shed on average twice a year. The body of the Cardigan is slightly longer than that of the Pembroke; both breeds have short legs
column6: placing their bodies close to the ground.[11][12] But they are not as square in outline as a typical Terrier
column7: or have an elongated body as great as that of a Dachshund. [27] There are only minor differences in the shape of the head
column8: both appear fox-like. The head of a Cardigan Welsh Corgi is typically larger than that of an equivalent Pembroke and has a larger nose. [1] It can take a few days following birth for the true color of a Corgi's coat to appear
column9: and this is particularly evident in those with tricolor or black and tan markings.[27]

column1: Corgis in the modern era often compete in dog agility trials
column3: showmanship
column4: flyball
column5: tracking
column6: and herding events. Herding instincts and trainability can be measured at non-competitive herding tests. Cardigan and Pembroke Corgis exhibiting basic herding instincts can be trained to compete in herding trials – known colloquially as a "mad run".[28] Welsh Corgis were once used to guard children.[13]

column1: The differences between the two breeds include bone structure
column3: and size. Cardigans are the larger of the two breeds
column4: with large rounded ears and a 12-inch-long (30 cm) fox-like
column5: flowing tail set in line with the body.[10] Though the Cardigan is allowed more colors than the Pembroke
column6: white should not predominate in its coat.[29] The Cardigan is a double-coated dog where the outer coat is dense
column8: and of medium length. The dog's undercoat is short
column10: and thick.[13] According to the breed standard
column11: the breed stands between 10.5–12.5 inches (27–32 cm) at the withers
column12: and should weigh between 30–38 pounds (14–17 kg). The skeletal structure of the Cardigan differs from the Pembroke
column13: in that there is a more exaggerated bend in the front two legs
column14: which fits around the ribcage of the animal. In addition
column15: the Cardigan is more heavily set than the Pembroke

column1: There are a greater number of colours of coat present in the Cardigan breed than the Pembroke
column2: with the breed standard allowing for a variety of shades of red
column3: sable
column4: and brindle. White markings are expected on this breed of Corgi
column5: and one with a black coat is allowed to have tan or brindle points under conformation show rules. Merle markings are present in the breed
column6: although this is normally restricted to blue merle.[2] There are several disqualification criteria in the breed standard for the purpose of confirmation shows. This would include drop ears
column9: or non-solid black noses in dogs without merle coloration.[30]

column1: Pembroke Welsh Corgi at Corgi Symphony

column2: [8] and are somewhat smaller in stature than the Cardigan. They are low-set
column3: intelligent
column4: strong
column5: and sturdy with stamina sufficient to work a day on the farm.[29] The common height at the withers is between 10–12 inches (25–30 cm)
column6: while a male dog of this breed should weigh no more than 30 pounds (14 kg)
column7: and a female 25 pounds (11 kg).[1] The tail is shorter than that of a Cardigan
column8: which can be accomplished through breeding or docking.[29] Historically
column9: the Pembroke was a breed with a natural bob tail (a very short tail). Due to the advent of tail docking in dogs
column10: [8] the bobtail was not aggressively pursued
column11: with breeders focusing instead on other characteristics
column12: and the tail artificially shortened if need be. Given that some countries now ban docking
column13: some breeders are again attempting to select dogs with the genes for natural bob tails.[31]

column1: Fewer colours of coat appear in the Pembroke breed. These include red
column3: tan
column4: fawn
column5: and black
column6: each of which can be with or without white markings. Plain white or grey coats can also be seen
column7: but these would be considered to be a serious fault for the purposes of conformation shows.[2] However
column8: the Pembroke Welsh Corgi has no specific disqualification criteria present in the breed standard.[30]

column1: Pembroke Welsh Corgis have two coats that vary in length along their body. The first coat is a shorter
column2: inner coat that is resistant to harsh weather
column3: while the outer coat is rougher and longer
column4: but still of medium length. The length of the coat differs on various parts of the body. Fur tends to be longer and thicker behind their fore and hind legs
column5: as well as underneath their bodies. In addition
column6: they appear to have more voluminous fur on their chest
column8: and shoulders. Pembroke Welsh corgis have shedding coats.[32]

column1: According to the Kennel Club Purebred Dog Health Survey conducted in 2004
column2: the two breeds had similar average lifespans: the median age at death was 12 years 3 months for Pembrokes
column3: and 12 years 2 months for Cardigans. The main causes of death were similar in both breeds: the primary causes were canine cancer and old age. However
column4: the Pembroke breed showed a higher proportion of deaths attributed to either kidney failure or urethral obstruction.[3][4] The survey showed that the breeds suffer from similar rates of ongoing health conditions
column5: with one exception. Whereas more than a quarter of Pembroke Welsh Corgis surveyed suffered from some type of eye condition
column6: only 6.1% of the Cardigan Corgis did.[3][4] Eye conditions typical in the Corgi breeds include progressive retinal atrophy
column7: which occurs more often in dogs over six years of age
column9: which again is more common in older dogs.[33] Cataracts in corgi are treatable with cataract extraction.[34] Similar percentages in the survey were seen in both breeds for issues relating to reproduction
column10: such as requiring caesarian sections and having false pregnancies. Further similarities were also seen related to musculoskeletal issues
column13: common in some types of dogs
column14: is rare in the Corgi breeds.[33]

column1: The Queen Mother Memorial bronze on The Mall
column3: shows her with two Corgis.

column1: Queen Elizabeth II had a long association with Corgis and it has been reported that she had said that "my corgis are family".[35] After a visit to Thomas Thynne
column3: Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret made it well known to their family that they liked the Corgis owned by the Marquess.[36][37] Their father
column4: Prince Albert
column5: Duke of York (later George VI)
column6: purchased the Pembroke Corgi Rozavel Golden Eagle
column7: from the Rozavel kennels in Surrey. It was renamed Dookie.[38]

column1: Princess Elizabeth was then given a Pembroke Corgi of her own
column3: for her 18th birthday in 1944.[39] She had a strong connection to the dog
column4: which was hidden under rugs in the Royal Carriage following her wedding to Prince Philip.[40] Susan became the progenitor of all the Corgis later owned by the Royal Household. The Queen bred ten generations of dogs from Susan
column5: owning personally more than 30 of the dogs
column6: which were either pure-bred Pembroke Welsh Corgis or crossbreed Corgi/Dachshunds called Dorgis.[41][42] The corgis – whose names included Whisky
column10: and Disco – slept in wicker baskets lined with cushions in their own room. It was reported that their diet

column1: It was reported in 2018 that the last of the Corgis belonging to Queen Elizabeth
column3: had died.[43][35] However
column4: in 2021 during the COVID-19 lockdown
column5: her son
column7: gave her a Corgi named Muick. This was followed by the gift from Andrew's daughters
column9: of another Corgi named Sandy to mark her 95th official birthday. On the death of the Queen in September 2022
column10: it was announced that Prince Andrew and his former wife
column13: would take care of Muick and Sandy.[35]

column1: Corgis have also appeared on screen
column2: stage and in novels. Corgis as characters were incorporated into the storybook fantasies Corgiville Fair
column3: The Great Corgiville Kidnapping
column4: and Corgiville Christmas of American author and illustrator Tasha Tudor.[44] In 1963
column5: a Corgi was featured in the Walt Disney film Little Dog Lost
column6: [45] which led to an increase in popularity for the breed within the United States.[46] A theatrical adaptation took place of Welsh author Roald Dahl's The BFG which toured the UK in 1991 required several different Corgis to perform on stage as those of Queen Elizabeth.[47] The Queen's Corgi is a Belgian animated film depicting the Queen's Corgis.[48]

column2: the crew has a super-intelligent Pembroke Welsh Corgi
column3: Ein
column4: on their ship.[49] The Top Shelf graphic novel Korgi plays on the folklore tradition of the Corgi as a faerie draft animal. It features the "Mollies" (fairy-like beings) who live in close relationship with the land and their Korgi friends
column5: who are based on and resemble the Welsh Corgi breeds.[50]

column1: Corgis appeared in Queen Elizabeth II's segment in the opening ceremony of the 2012 London Olympics when she is escorted by James Bond from Buckingham Palace to the stadium.[51][52]
The American animated TV series Infinity Train features a country of anthropomorphic corgis known as Coriginia ruled by King Atticus
column2: styled "Uniter of the Cardigans and Pembrokes".[53]
